title: 2 Samuel Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 7.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7:2, what did King David say about his dwelling and the ark of God?
options: He dwells in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells within curtains
He dwells in a tent, and the ark of God is in a house of stone
He dwells in a house of brick, and the ark of God is outside
He dwells in a palace, and the ark of God is in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He dwells in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells within curtains
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:2 states that David said he dwells in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells within curtains.

questions.question: Who did King David speak to about building a house for the ark of God, according to 2 Samuel 7:2?
options: Nathan the prophet
Samuel the prophet
Gad the seer
Ahijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Nathan the prophet
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:2 clearly states that David spoke to Nathan the prophet about this matter.

questions.question: What was Nathan's initial response to King David about building the house, according to 2 Samuel 7:3?
options: Go, do all that is in thine heart; for the LORD is with thee
Wait and seek the LORD's guidance first
Do not build the house; it is not the right time
Ask the elders of Israel before proceeding
questions.correctAnswer: Go, do all that is in thine heart; for the LORD is with thee
questions.explanation: Nathan initially told David to proceed because the LORD was with him, as stated in 2 Samuel 7:3.

questions.question: What did the LORD say to Nathan about David building a house for Him, as recorded in 2 Samuel 7:5?
options: Shalt thou build me an house for me to dwell in?
Build a temple that will last forever
Build a house of stone for my presence
Prepare a place for me in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Shalt thou build me an house for me to dwell in?
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:5 records the LORD's question to Nathan asking if David should build Him a house to dwell in.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7:6, where has the LORD dwelt since bringing Israel out of Egypt?
options: In a tent and in a tabernacle
In a cedar house
In a stone temple
On Mount Zion
questions.correctAnswer: In a tent and in a tabernacle
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:6 says the LORD has not dwelt in any house but has walked in a tent and tabernacle.

questions.question: From what was David taken to be ruler over Israel, according to 2 Samuel 7:8?
options: From the sheepcote, from following the sheep
From the city gates
From the battlefields
From the palace of Saul
questions.correctAnswer: From the sheepcote, from following the sheep
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:8 states that God took David from the sheepcote, from following the sheep, to be ruler over Israel.

questions.question: What promise does the LORD make about David's seed in 2 Samuel 7:12?
options: I will set up thy seed after thee, and establish his kingdom
I will destroy the kingdom of thy seed
I will make thy seed wander
I will appoint no successor to thy throne
questions.correctAnswer: I will set up thy seed after thee, and establish his kingdom
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:12 promises God will set up David's seed after him and establish his kingdom.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7:14, what will God do if David's seed commits iniquity?
options: Chasten him with the rod of men and stripes of the children of men
Ignore the sin entirely
Destroy him completely
Send a prophet to warn him
questions.correctAnswer: Chasten him with the rod of men and stripes of the children of men
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 says God would chasten David's seed with the rod of men and stripes if he commits iniquity.

questions.question: How long will David's house and kingdom be established, according to 2 Samuel 7:16?
options: Forever
For a hundred years
Until the exile
For seven generations
questions.correctAnswer: Forever
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:16 promises David's house and kingdom shall be established forever.

questions.question: What question does King David ask the LORD in 2 Samuel 7:18?
options: Who am I, O Lord GOD? and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto?
Why have you forsaken me, O LORD?
What shall I do for my people, O God?
Will you build me a temple, LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Who am I, O Lord GOD? and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto?
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:18 records David's humble question recognizing God's blessings upon him and his house.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 7:9, God made David a great name like the great men of the earth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:9 states God made David a great name like the great men of the earth.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Samuel 7:10, God promises that Israel will be afflicted by wicked people forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:10 promises Israel will dwell in their own place and not be afflicted by wicked people any more.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Samuel 7:25 is a prayer asking the LORD to establish His word concerning David and his house forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:25 records David's prayer asking God to establish His promises forever.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Samuel 7:26: 'And let thy name be magnified for ever, saying, The LORD of hosts is the God over ______:'
options: Israel
the nations
the earth
David
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:26 says 'The LORD of hosts is the God over Israel.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Samuel 7:28: 'And now, O Lord GOD, thou art that God, and thy words be true, and thou hast promised this ______ unto thy servant:'
options: goodness
judgment
truth
victory
questions.correctAnswer: goodness
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:28 states God has promised 'this goodness' unto His servant.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7:23, what is unique about the nation of Israel?
options: There is no other nation like Israel, whom God redeemed to be His people
Israel has many gods like other nations
Israel was never redeemed from Egypt
Israel is like all other nations on earth
questions.correctAnswer: There is no other nation like Israel, whom God redeemed to be His people
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:23 emphasizes Israel's uniqueness as God's redeemed people.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling anxious about future uncertainties. Based on 2 Samuel 7, what biblical truth about God's promises would you share to encourage faith and trust?
options: God promises to establish David's kingdom forever, showing His faithfulness to keep His covenant.
God only helps those who build grand houses for Him.
God's promises are conditional on human strength and power.
God does not intervene in the affairs of kings or leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to establish David's kingdom forever, showing His faithfulness to keep His covenant.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Samuel 7:12-16 reveal God's promise to establish David's house and kingdom forever, demonstrating His faithfulness and sovereignty, which encourages believers to trust God despite uncertainties.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 teach us about humility and gratitude in prayer through King David's response to God's promises?
options: David acknowledges he is unworthy and marvels at God's kindness.
David demands more blessings because of his past victories.
David remains silent and does not respond to God's word.
David boasts about his achievements before God.
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledges he is unworthy and marvels at God's kindness.
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:18-20, David humbly recognizes his lowly status and expresses gratitude for God's great promises, modeling a heart of humility and thankfulness in prayer.

questions.question: A believer struggles with feeling insignificant in God's plan. According to 2 Samuel 7, what truth about God's choice and purpose would you share?
options: God chose David from being a shepherd to lead His people, showing God uses the humble for great purposes.
God only uses people from noble families for important tasks.
God's plans are limited to those with political power.
God prefers those who build grand houses and temples.
questions.correctAnswer: God chose David from being a shepherd to lead His people, showing God uses the humble for great purposes.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:8-9 explains God took David from tending sheep to be ruler over Israel, teaching us God values humble beginnings and calls ordinary people to serve His purposes.

questions.question: In the context of family life and parenting, what principle from 2 Samuel 7 can help believers understand God's discipline and mercy?
options: God disciplines His children with love but never removes His mercy.
God punishes without mercy to discourage sin.
God ignores the faults of His children.
God's mercy is removed immediately after sin.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines His children with love but never removes His mercy.
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Samuel 7:14-15 shows God promises to chasten with discipline but His mercy will not depart, teaching a balance of loving correction and steadfast grace in family and spiritual life.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 encourage believers to live with contentment and trust in God's provision?
options: David was content resting in the peace God gave after his enemies were defeated.
David constantly sought to build a grand temple for God immediately.
David trusted only in his own strength and plans.
David ignored God's rest and continued fighting.
questions.correctAnswer: David was content resting in the peace God gave after his enemies were defeated.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:1-2 describes the king resting from enemies and reflecting on God's provision, encouraging believers to be content and trust God's timing and care.

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 7 teach about the importance of obedience and listening to God's word when making decisions?
options: Nathan initially agreed with David but then was corrected by God's word, showing the need to confirm decisions through God's guidance.
Nathan immediately ignored David's idea and told him not to build.
David acted without consulting anyone about God's will.
God's word was not relevant to David's plans.
questions.correctAnswer: Nathan initially agreed with David but then was corrected by God's word, showing the need to confirm decisions through God's guidance.
questions.explanation: In verses 2 Samuel 7:2-4, Nathan first encourages David but then receives God's word correcting the plan, demonstrating the importance of seeking God's direction before acting.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with perseverance through trials and temptation. Based on 2 Samuel 7, how can the promise of God's enduring covenant help sustain their faith?
options: God's promise to establish David's house forever reminds believers of His unchanging faithfulness even in hardships.
God abandons His promises when trials come.
God only supports believers who never struggle.
God's covenant is temporary and conditional on perfect behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: God's promise to establish David's house forever reminds believers of His unchanging faithfulness even in hardships.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Samuel 7:16 and 7:11 affirm God's everlasting covenant and rest from enemies, encouraging believers to persevere trusting God's enduring faithfulness.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 teach about the role of prayer and personal devotion in responding to God's promises?
options: David responds to God's word with heartfelt prayer, recognizing God's greatness and seeking His continued blessing.
David ignores God's promises and does not pray.
David demands immediate fulfillment without prayer.
David prays only after all promises are fulfilled.
questions.correctAnswer: David responds to God's word with heartfelt prayer, recognizing God's greatness and seeking His continued blessing.
questions.explanation: In verses 2 Samuel 7:18-29, David prays earnestly, praising God and asking for His blessing, showing the importance of prayer in spiritual response and devotion.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 7, God had never asked any of the tribes of Israel to build Him a house before David's time.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Samuel 7:7 states God never asked any tribe to build a house for Him, highlighting that God dwelt in tents and tabernacles before David's time.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Samuel 7 teaches that God's mercy can depart from His chosen leaders if they sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 7:14-15, even if the leader commits iniquity and is disciplined, God's mercy does not depart as it did from Saul, showing steadfast mercy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In 2 Samuel 7, God took David from the ___________ to be ruler over Israel.
options: sheepcote
palace
battlefield
city
questions.correctAnswer: sheepcote
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Samuel 7:8 describes God taking David from the sheepcote, symbolizing humble origins and God's calling to leadership.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 instruct believers about integrity and honesty in their relationship with God and others?
options: David honestly acknowledges his position and relies on God's word rather than his own plans.
David hides his intentions from Nathan the prophet.
David tries to deceive God by building the temple secretly.
David ignores God's instructions and acts on impulse.
questions.correctAnswer: David honestly acknowledges his position and relies on God's word rather than his own plans.
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:2-3 and 7:18-20, David openly shares his thoughts with Nathan and humbly accepts God's word, highlighting integrity and truthful reliance on God.

questions.question: A believer wants to serve faithfully in church life and fellowship. What example from 2 Samuel 7 encourages faithful service despite waiting for God's timing?
options: David waited patiently for God's promise about his house instead of rushing to build the temple.
David immediately built the temple without waiting for God's word.
David refused to follow God's prophet Nathan.
David disregarded God's covenant and served selfishly.
questions.correctAnswer: David waited patiently for God's promise about his house instead of rushing to build the temple.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Samuel 7:4-17 show David receiving God's timing and promise through Nathan, teaching believers to patiently serve and wait on God's direction.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 demonstrate the importance of generosity and stewardship in spiritual life?
options: David recognizes God's provision and seeks to honor Him with a proper house, reflecting stewardship of blessings.
David keeps all his wealth for himself.
David is indifferent to God's presence and provision.
David uses God's gifts for personal gain only.
questions.correctAnswer: David recognizes God's provision and seeks to honor Him with a proper house, reflecting stewardship of blessings.
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:2, David expresses desire to build a cedar house for God’s ark, showing respect and stewardship over God's blessings and presence.

questions.question: Based on 2 Samuel 7, how should believers respond to God's faithfulness and mighty works in their lives?
options: With praise, acknowledgment of God's greatness, and trust in His unique sovereignty.
With doubt and questioning of God's power.
By relying solely on human wisdom.
By ignoring God's promises.
questions.correctAnswer: With praise, acknowledgment of God's greatness, and trust in His unique sovereignty.
questions.explanation: David’s prayer in 2 Samuel 7:22-24 praises God’s greatness and uniqueness, encouraging believers to respond with worship and trust.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 teach about reconciliation and forgiveness within the family or community context?
options: God promises mercy and discipline, indicating correction is for restoration, not rejection.
God immediately rejects those who sin without chance for repentance.
Forgiveness is not necessary in leadership or family life.
Discipline is punishment without hope for reconciliation.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises mercy and discipline, indicating correction is for restoration, not rejection.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Samuel 7:14-15 show God’s discipline coupled with mercy, teaching believers the importance of forgiveness and restoration in relationships.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 7.

questions.question: What was King David's initial concern that led him to speak to Nathan the prophet?
options: He wanted to build a house for the ark of God
He was worried about his enemies attacking
He sought to expand his kingdom's borders
He desired to establish a new priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: He wanted to build a house for the ark of God
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:2, David expresses his concern that while he lives in a house of cedar, the ark of God remains within curtains, indicating his desire to build a proper house for the ark.

questions.question: How did Nathan initially respond to David's desire to build a house for the LORD?
options: He encouraged him to proceed
He advised waiting for a sign
He forbade him from building
He sought counsel from the priests first
questions.correctAnswer: He encouraged him to proceed
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 7:3, Nathan told David to do all that was in his heart because the LORD was with him, showing initial encouragement.

questions.question: What significant message did the LORD reveal to Nathan during the night?
options: David was not to build a house for God
David would become king over all nations
A descendant of David would establish God's kingdom forever
The temple would be built immediately
questions.correctAnswer: A descendant of David would establish God's kingdom forever
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:12-13, the LORD reveals to Nathan that David’s offspring will build a house for His name and that His kingdom will be established forever.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I took thee from the ________, from following the sheep, to be ruler over my people, over Israel.'
options: sheepcote
fields
mountains
pastures
questions.correctAnswer: sheepcote
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Samuel 7:8 states that God took David from the sheepcote to be ruler over Israel, emphasizing his humble origins.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes God’s dwelling before David’s time, according to 2 Samuel 7?
options: In a tent and a tabernacle
In a cedar house
In a stone temple
On Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: In a tent and a tabernacle
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:6 reveals that God had not dwelt in a house but walked in a tent and tabernacle since the Exodus.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7, what is the significance of the 'house' that God promises to establish for David?
options: It refers to David’s dynastic lineage and kingdom
It is a physical temple David will build
It symbolizes Israel’s military strength
It is a new priesthood order
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to David’s dynastic lineage and kingdom
questions.explanation: The 'house' in 2 Samuel 7:11-16 primarily refers to David’s descendants and the eternal nature of his kingdom, not just a physical building.

questions.question: True or False: God told Nathan that He had asked any of the tribes of Israel to build Him a house of cedar before.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:7, God says He never commanded any tribe of Israel to build Him a house of cedar, highlighting this as a new promise to David.

questions.question: How does David respond to God’s promises as recorded in 2 Samuel 7?
options: With humility and prayer of praise
With immediate plans to build the temple
With skepticism and doubt
With anger at his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: With humility and prayer of praise
questions.explanation: David responds in 2 Samuel 7:18-29 with humility, recognizing God’s greatness, and prays for the establishment of his house forever.

questions.question: What is the covenantal relationship described between God and David’s offspring in 2 Samuel 7?
options: God will be a father to David’s son, who will be His son
David’s son will be a priest for Israel
David’s son will build a palace of gold
David’s son will conquer all nations
questions.correctAnswer: God will be a father to David’s son, who will be His son
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 explains that God will be a father to David’s descendant, establishing a special father-son covenant relationship.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents the theological theme foreshadowed in the promise of an eternal throne to David’s house?
options: The Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ
The immediate political stability of Israel
The construction of Solomon’s temple
The division of the kingdom after David
questions.correctAnswer: The Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The promise of an eternal kingdom (2 Samuel 7:13,16) foreshadows the coming of the Messiah, recognized in the New Testament as Jesus Christ.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in God’s speech to David in 2 Samuel 7, particularly in the promise of an everlasting kingdom?
options: Covenantal promise
Parable
Chiasm
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Covenantal promise
questions.explanation: The passage is a classic example of a covenantal promise, where God establishes an unbreakable agreement with David and his descendants (2 Samuel 7:12-16).

questions.question: In the historical context of ancient Near Eastern monarchies, how is God's promise to David in 2 Samuel 7 unique?
options: It guarantees an eternal dynasty rather than a temporary reign
It commands David to conquer neighboring kingdoms
It requires David to build a temple immediately
It establishes David as a god
questions.correctAnswer: It guarantees an eternal dynasty rather than a temporary reign
questions.explanation: Unlike typical ancient Near Eastern kingship promises, God’s covenant with David (2 Samuel 7:16) assures an everlasting dynasty, emphasizing divine sovereignty over time.

questions.question: Which phrase used in 2 Samuel 7 highlights the exclusivity of God’s relationship with Israel?
options: "Neither is there any God beside thee"
"A house of cedar"
"The rod of men"
"From following the sheep"
questions.correctAnswer: "Neither is there any God beside thee"
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:22, David declares the uniqueness of God, affirming that there is no other God besides Him, underscoring Israel's exclusive covenant.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7, what role did God say He had taken in relation to David’s victories over his enemies?
options: God was with David wherever he went and cut off his enemies
God allowed David to fight alone
God sent angels to fight for David
God delayed David’s victories
questions.correctAnswer: God was with David wherever he went and cut off his enemies
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:9 states that God was with David and eliminated his enemies to establish his great name.

questions.question: True or False: David’s prayer in 2 Samuel 7 includes a request for God’s name to be magnified forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:26, David prays that God’s name be magnified forever, acknowledging God’s sovereignty and glory.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the rod of men' symbolize in the context of God’s discipline mentioned in 2 Samuel 7?
options: Human authority used by God to chasten iniquity
A shepherd’s tool for guiding sheep
A symbol of David’s power
An instrument for building the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Human authority used by God to chasten iniquity
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 uses 'the rod of men' to denote the human means of discipline God employs when His son commits iniquity, emphasizing divine justice.

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason does God give David for not building Him a house in 2 Samuel 7?
options: God has never dwelt in a house since bringing Israel from Egypt
God preferred the tabernacle made of gold
David was not worthy to build God's house
The ark of God was too sacred to be moved
questions.correctAnswer: God has never dwelt in a house since bringing Israel from Egypt
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:5-6 explains that God has not dwelt in any house since bringing Israel out of Egypt but has moved in tents, indicating God's sovereign choice and humility. This is consistent with Exodus 25:8-9, where God commanded a tabernacle, and Hebrews 8:5, which speaks of the earthly sanctuary as a pattern.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 7, what was God's initial response to David's plan to build a house for Him?
options: God questioned the wisdom of building a house
God immediately approved and blessed the plan
God instructed Nathan to tell David not to build the house
God said David must build it with his own hands
questions.correctAnswer: God instructed Nathan to tell David not to build the house
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:5, God commands Nathan to tell David that he shall not build God a house, indicating divine sovereignty over worship and temple construction. This contrasts with Solomon's later building under God's direction (1 Kings 6:11-13).

questions.question: What does God say about David's past and his rise to kingship?
options: God took David from following sheep to rule Israel
David was born into royalty and thus chosen
David conquered all his enemies by his own strength
David was appointed by the elders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God took David from following sheep to rule Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:8 states God took David from the sheepcote to be ruler, showing God's sovereign election and grace, consistent with God's calling of lowly individuals like Moses (Exodus 3) and Paul (Acts 9).

questions.question: What promise does God make about David's descendants in 2 Samuel 7?
options: God will establish the kingdom of David's seed forever
David's descendants will build many houses
David's lineage will end with his son Solomon
David's descendants will be priests of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will establish the kingdom of David's seed forever
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:12-13 promises that David's offspring will build God's house and that his kingdom will be established forever, a messianic prophecy fulfilled ultimately in Christ (Luke 1:32-33; Acts 2:29-31).

questions.question: How does God describe His relationship with David's promised descendant?
options: I will be his father, and he shall be my son
He shall be a servant to my people Israel
He shall reign only over Judah
He shall be a prophet like Moses
questions.correctAnswer: I will be his father, and he shall be my son
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:14 reveals God's father-son relationship with David's descendant, a unique covenant indicating intimacy and authority, echoed in Hebrews 1:5 and Psalm 2:7 concerning the Messiah.

questions.question: What does God say about disciplining David's son if he commits iniquity?
options: God will chasten him with the rod of men
God will immediately remove him from the throne
God will not discipline him because of mercy
God will allow the people to judge him
questions.correctAnswer: God will chasten him with the rod of men
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:14, God declares He will discipline David's son if he sins, demonstrating God's just and redemptive governance, consistent with Proverbs 3:12 and Hebrews 12:6 about divine chastening.

questions.question: How does God contrast His mercy toward David's house with His treatment of Saul?
options: God's mercy will not depart from David's house as it did from Saul's
God will show equal mercy to both houses
Saul's house will be established forever like David's
David's house will be rejected like Saul's
questions.correctAnswer: God's mercy will not depart from David's house as it did from Saul's
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:15 highlights God's enduring mercy to David's lineage unlike Saul, whose house was rejected, illustrating divine election and covenant faithfulness, reflected in Romans 11:29 regarding God's irrevocable gifts.

questions.question: What does David do after Nathan delivers God's message?
options: David prays humbly before the Lord
David immediately begins to build the temple
David consults other leaders for advice
David writes a psalm of lament
questions.correctAnswer: David prays humbly before the Lord
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:18-29 records David sitting before the Lord and offering a prayer of humility and praise, showing the proper response to divine revelation, in line with other biblical prayers like Hannah’s (1 Samuel 2) and Solomon’s prayer (1 Kings 8).

questions.question: How does David describe God's greatness in his prayer?
options: There is none like the LORD God; He alone is God
God is one among many gods
God's power is limited
God is distant and unapproachable
questions.correctAnswer: There is none like the LORD God; He alone is God
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:22, David proclaims God's uniqueness and greatness, affirming monotheism and God's incomparable nature, consistent with Isaiah 45:5 and Deuteronomy 6:4.

questions.question: According to David's prayer, what distinguishes Israel among the nations?
options: God redeemed Israel to be His people and to make a name for Himself
Israel conquered all nations by military power
Israel was chosen for its righteousness
Israel worshipped many gods like other nations
questions.correctAnswer: God redeemed Israel to be His people and to make a name for Himself
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:23 explains God's redemption of Israel as His people, demonstrating divine grace and covenant, paralleling Exodus 19:5-6 and Isaiah 43:20-21.

questions.question: What does David ask God to do concerning the word God spoke about his house?
options: Establish it forever and do as He promised
Delay the promise until later generations
Make it conditional upon Israel's obedience
Forget the promise as David is unworthy
questions.correctAnswer: Establish it forever and do as He promised
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 7:25, David petitions God to confirm His word about David's house forever, reflecting trust in God's covenant, consistent with Psalm 89:28-37 and Jeremiah 33:17-21.

questions.question: How does David characterize his motivation for praying this prayer in 2 Samuel 7?
options: Because God revealed He would build David a house
Because David wanted to build the temple himself
Because the people demanded a prayer
Because Nathan instructed him to pray
questions.correctAnswer: Because God revealed He would build David a house
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:27-28 shows David's prayer motivated by God's revelation to build him a house, emphasizing divine initiative in covenant promises, consistent with Abraham's response in Genesis 15:6 and Moses' intercession (Exodus 32).

questions.question: What does David ask God to do at the end of his prayer in 2 Samuel 7?
options: Bless the house of David so it may continue forever
Destroy all enemies of Israel
Grant David long life
Make the temple visible to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: Bless the house of David so it may continue forever
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:29 concludes with David asking for God's blessing on his house to endure forever, expressing faith in God's covenantal faithfulness, echoed in Psalm 132:11-12 and Isaiah 9:7.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God's promise to establish David's throne forever?
options: It points to the messianic kingdom fulfilled in Jesus Christ
It means David's physical descendants will never fall
It was fulfilled fully by Solomon's reign
It refers only to Israel's political stability
questions.correctAnswer: It points to the messianic kingdom fulfilled in Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 7:16’s promise of an eternal throne is a foundational messianic prophecy fulfilled ultimately in Christ (Luke 1:32-33; Revelation 11:15) establishing God's everlasting kingdom, transcending earthly monarchy.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 7 reflect God's covenantal faithfulness to His people?
options: By confirming an everlasting covenant with David's house
By promising immediate peace without trials
By requiring perfect obedience for blessings
By limiting blessings only to Israel's priests
questions.correctAnswer: By confirming an everlasting covenant with David's house
questions.explanation: The chapter underscores God’s covenant with David (2 Samuel 7:16, 24), demonstrating divine faithfulness, consistent with God's covenant with Abraham (Genesis 17:7) and the New Covenant (Jeremiah 31:33).

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 7 teach about God's sovereignty over history and human plans?
options: God directs human plans according to His divine purposes
God allows humans to do as they please without interference
God reacts passively to human initiatives
Human plans always override God's will
questions.correctAnswer: God directs human plans according to His divine purposes
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God overriding David's plan to build a temple and revealing His sovereign plan instead (2 Samuel 7:5-7), consistent with Proverbs 19:21 and Isaiah 46:10 about God's control over human affairs.
